importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The FAA imposed a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX starting in January 2024, following a safety incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four key bolts.
The FAA and Boeing announced the lifting of the production cap, allowing Boeing to increase 737 MAX production to 42 planes per month as of this date.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The period from January 2024 to October 2025 marks the duration during which the FAA imposed and then lifted a production cap on Boeing’s 737 MAX aircraft, reflecting a critical phase in the company's recovery from a safety crisis.

keyTakeAways: The FAA has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing's 737 MAX, allowing the company to increase output to 42 planes per month.
The production cap was initially imposed in January 2024 following a mid-air emergency involving a new Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that lacked four critical bolts.
FAA safety inspectors conducted extensive reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure the safety of the increased production rate.
Boeing plans to immediately begin producing 737 MAX aircraft at the new rate of 42 per month.
The decision reflects a significant milestone in Boeing’s recovery after a major safety incident and the subsequent regulatory scrutiny.

namedEntities.name: Boeing
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major U.S. aerospace manufacturer, known for producing commercial aircraft such as the 737 MAX series.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boeing is central to the article as the company whose 737 MAX production has been restricted and is now being allowed to increase output after a safety review.

namedEntities.name: 737 MAX
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A commercial jetliner model produced by Boeing, previously affected by safety issues following two fatal crashes.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The 737 MAX is the specific aircraft model whose production rate has been adjusted, signaling a major shift in Boeing’s manufacturing strategy and regulatory approval after safety concerns.

namedEntities.name: Federal Aviation Administration (FAA)
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The U.S. government agency responsible for regulating aviation safety and air traffic.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The FAA imposed and later lifted the production cap on Boeing’s 737 MAX, showing its role in overseeing safety standards and approving increased manufacturing output.

namedEntities.name: Alaska Airlines
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A U.S. commercial airline that operates flights using Boeing 737 MAX aircraft.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Alaska Airlines is referenced as the airline involved in a 2024 mid-air emergency with a 737 MAX 9 that lacked four critical bolts, triggering the initial production cap.

namedEntities.name: Kelly Ortberg
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kelly Ortberg, as Boeing’s CEO, was directly involved in the communication with FAA Administrator Bryan Bedford regarding the production increase.

namedEntities.name: Bryan Bedford
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: The Administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Bryan Bedford played a key role in confirming Boeing’s ability to raise production levels, underscoring the FAA’s regulatory oversight and approval process.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The Federal Aviation Administration has lifted a 38-plane-per-month production cap on Boeing’s 737 MAX, allowing the company to increase output to 42 planes per month. This decision follows a 2024 incident involving an Alaska Airlines 737 MAX 9 that was missing four critical bolts, which initially triggered the cap. The FAA conducted thorough safety reviews of Boeing’s production lines to ensure the increased rate can be maintained safely. Boeing plans to immediately begin producing at the new rate, with both company leadership and regulatory officials emphasizing safety and quality as top priorities. This marks a significant milestone in Boeing’s recovery from a previous safety crisis.
title: Boeing can hike 737 MAX production to 42 planes per month, FAA says
